title: Shipbuilding and World Trade Table MCQ 2

content.prompt: Which of the following best describes a conclusion about the relationship between steamships and world trade in the late nineteenth century that is supported by the data in the table?

choices.label: North America had roughly twice the share of world trade as Latin America had because it possessed almost twice as many steamships.
Africa and Oceania’s share of world trade was nearly equivalent to Latin America’s share of world trade because all three regions had roughly the same number of steamships.
The fact that North America had only the third largest share of world trade by region roughly corresponds to its share of the total number of sailing vessels by region.
Europe’s dominance in the total number of steamships roughly correlates to its dominance in world trade.

topic.text: 5.4: Industrialization Spreads in the Period from 1750 to 1900

skill.text: Skill 5.A: Identify patterns among or connections between historical developments and processes.
